coredata.dc:title: Electrorheological properties of a suspension of a mesoporous molecular sieve (MCM-41)

Cho, Min S
Kang, Kyung-Ku
Ahn, Wha-Seung
coredata.dc:description: We report on the electrorheological (ER) properties of an ER fluid made of suspensions of MCM-41 particles in silicone oil under a high electric field. The effect of the particle concentration on the ER performance was also investigated. Typical behaviors of shear stresses and apparent shear viscosities as functions of both the electric field and the shear rate were observed for the ER system with a 20 wt.% particle suspension. In addition, a water content of ca. 6 wt.% in the MCM-41 particles was found to be responsible for their ER effect.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic diagram of the particle fibrillation of an ER fluid under an applied electric field.
TGA thermodiagram of Si-MCM-41 used in this paper.
Particle size distribution of Si-MCM-41 obtained by laser particle size analysis.

(a) Shear stress as a function of shear rate at various electric fields; (b) a plot of Fig. 7(a) in a linear scale; (c) apparent shear viscosity as a function of the shear rate at various electric fields for 20 wt.% MCM-41 in silicone oil.

head.ce:title: Electrorheological properties of a suspension of a mesoporous molecular sieve (MCM-41)

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Polymer Science and Engineering, Inha University, Inchon, 402-751, South Korea

ce:affiliation.ce:label: b
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemical Engineering, Inha University, Inchon, 402-751, South Korea

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We report on the electrorheological (ER) properties of an ER fluid made of suspensions of MCM-41 particles in silicone oil under a high electric field. The effect of the particle concentration on the ER performance was also investigated. Typical behaviors of shear stresses and apparent shear viscosities as functions of both the electric field and the shear rate were observed for the ER system with a 20 wt.% particle suspension. In addition, a water content of ca. 6 wt.% in the MCM-41 particles was found to be responsible for their ER effect.

ce:section.ce:para: Electrorheological (ER) fluids of the rheological properties can be changed by an imposed electric field [1]. Commonly, they are composed of a suspension of micron-sized particles in a non-conducting fluid. However, single-phase ER fluids such as solutions of liquid crystalline polymers were recently reported [2]. The variation of the rheological properties of ER fluids under an electric field is caused by a characteristic fibrillation; the strings of the particles attracting each other are oriented along the direction of the electric field (Fig. 1). In the absence of an electric field, the fluid exhibits either a Newtonian or a non-Newtonian fluid-like behavior, depending on the particle concentration.

Under the influence of an electric field, ER fluids suddenly change from a fluid-like state to a solid-like state, due to the fibril structures of the particles, and a stress is required to break the chain-like or columnar structure, and then make it flow. This stress, referred to as yield stress, is field dependent and is the main characteristic of an ER fluid. ER fluids also show an increase in their shear viscosities of several orders of magnitude at low shear rate conditions.

The fibril structures in ER fluids under an electric field causing the phenomena mentioned above, should originate from the attractive force between the particles. The attractive force is usually explained by the polarization model [3] or the conduction model [4]. The conduction model does not consider the effect of flow on ER, because the calculation of the ER effect is based on the conduction between the stationary adjacent particles. Hence, the conduction model is a static model rather than a dynamic one [5]. Recently, Hao et al. [6] proposed that the slow polarization, i.e. the interfacial polarization, mainly contributed to the ER effect, and the fibril structures in ER fluids under an electric field were formed by particle rotation. From the viewpoint of the polarization model, the electric field applied to an ER fluid polarizes the particles with a migration of mobile species such as electrons or ions. A dipolar field is then generated around each particle, so that the local field is distorted and the particles have a dipole moment. These induced dipoles attract each other and cause the particles to form chains or fibrillar structures in the direction of the field [7].

ER suspensions are, in general, divided into two categories, namely, intrinsic polarizable (anhydrous) and extrinsic polarizable (hydrous) systems [7]. The former usually contains semiconducting polymer particles such as polyanilines [8,9], poly(acene quinone) radicals [10,11], copolyaniline [12], and poly(p-phenylene) [13] which are polarized in an electric field due to electrons within the polymer molecule, whilst those in the latter are materials that can be polarized in the electric field with additives such as water and alcohol, known to be hydrous systems. Representatives of the extrinsic polarizable ER systems are various inorganic particles such as silica, alumina and clays, polysaccharides, and polyelectrolytes [10]. It is generally believed that the anhydrous ER systems are superior to the hydrous systems in applications, due to their higher thermal and dispersion stabilities.

Commercial zeolites have also been used as suspension materials for ER fluids [14â18]. Recently, Cho et al. [18] studied rheological and dielectric properties of ER fluids prepared from the commercial zeolites 3A, 5A and 13X suspended in silicone oil and found that the ER fluid containing zeolite 13X showed the best performance among the zeolitic ER fluids investigated.

On the other hand, the recent discovery of mesoporous M41S molecular sieve materials has attracted considerable interest. They occur either as a hexagonal, a cubic, or an unstable lamellar phase which are known as MCM-41, MCM-48 and MCM-50, respectively [19â21]. Several related mesoporous materials with different structures have also been reported [22â26].

Since mesoporous materials possess large surface areas and the size of pores can be tuned within 20â100 Ã by varying the preparation conditions, a large number of potential applications of these materials are expected to emerge in the area of catalysis, separation, adsorption and advanced materials [27â29].

In this study, synthetic MCM-41 was dispersed in silicone oil with a particle concentration of 5 to 20 wt.%, and these suspensions were evaluated as ER fluids as a part of our continuing research interest in various potential ER materials. We also estimated the potential of mesoporous materials as a dispersed phase of ER suspensions.

MCM-41 was prepared following the procedure of Ryoo et al [30]. Ludox AS-40 (SiO2, 40 wt.% colloidal silica in water, Dupont) was added under vigorous stirring to a 40 wt.% TEAOH (tetraethylammonium hydroxide) solution. This solution mixture was then combined with a 25 wt.% CTMACl (cetyltrimethylammonium chloride) solution, and the gel obtained was stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Subsequently, the mixture was placed in an autoclave and kept at 373 K for 24 h in a conventional oven. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, and acetic acid was added dropwise under vigorous stirring until the pH was â10.2. This mixture was then heated again to 373 K for 24 h. The pH adjustment and subsequent heating were repeated twice. The solid product obtained was filtered and the surfactant was extracted from MCM-41 in EtOHâHCl solution at room temperature (1g solid/EtOH 20 ml+HCl 2 ml). After drying, it was calcined in air at 823 K.

The XRD pattern of the calcined MCM-41 sample was obtained with a powder X-ray diffractometer (Philips, PW-1700) using a CuKÎ± radiation (40 kV, 25 mA). The nitrogen adsorption isotherms and specific surface areas were determined using a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 automatic analyzer. The morphology of the samples was examined by SEM (Hitachi, S-4200) and TEM (Philips, CM200). Particle size distributions were measured using a laser scattering particle size analyzer (Malvern, SYS 4700). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out using a TA Instrument 951 to measure the water content of the sample (Fig. 2); ca. 10 mg of the sample was placed in a quartz bucket and heated at a rate of 10Â°C/min in an N2 atmosphere. The water content in MCM-41 was about 5 wt.% calculated by the weight loss around 100oC.

The ER fluids were prepared by dispersing the MCM-41 particles in an anhydrous silicone oil with particle concentrations of 5, 10 and 20 wt.%. The silicone oil was dried with molecular sieves before use to get rid of any traces of water. The as-synthesized particles were used as a powder, however, for better dispersion and wettability of MCM-41 in silicone oil, the ER fluids were sonificated with an ultrasonicator during sample preparation. The ER properties were then measured at 25Â±0.1Â°C using a rotation type rheometer (MC120, Physica) equipped with a high voltage generator. This unit consisted of a concentric cylinder with a 1.06 mm gap between a bob and a cup, and a static electric field perpendicular to the flow direction was applied to the measuring unit through the cup; the inner wall of the cup was the positive electrode, and the bob was grounded.

An electric field was applied to an ER fluid for 3 min before the measurement, in order to equilibrate the internal structure of the particles in the ER fluid. The flow curves for each ER fluid were obtained at a controlled shear rate.

Fig. 3 shows the XRD pattern of the calcined MCM-41 prepared. The pattern corresponds to regular hexagonal channels of the MCM-41 structure with a strong (100) peak followed by three (110) (200) and (211) peaks in the 2Î¸ ranges of 2â7Â°. The BET surface area of the sample was â950 m2/g with an average BJH diameter of 31 Ã .

The particle morphology of MCM-41 materials is reported to be variable, and the surface texture exhibits a range from smooth through pitted [21]. According to our SEM analysis, small primary particles of 80â120 nm were agglomerated (Fig. 4). The size distribution of the agglomerated particles determined by laser particle size analysis is shown in Fig. 5. The average size is â700 nm with a skewed size distribution till 4000 nm. The TEM image in Fig. 6 shows a uniform hexagonal pore structure. MCM-41 is hydrophilic, and the water content of the calcined MCM-41 sample determined by TGA was â6 wt.% which agreed with the data of Borade and Clearfield [31].

Figs. 7(a) and (b) shows the typical ER behavior of shear stresses and apparent shear viscosities as a function of the shear rate under various applied electric fields for MCM-41 ER 20 wt.% in silicone oil. The ER fluid weakly solidified by a high electric field is considered as a Bingham, which needs a force (e.g. yield stress) to start flowing. However, the shear stress behavior as a function of shear rate applied in Fig. 7(a) is quite different from a classical Bingham fluid. Shear stresses that slightly decreased or remained constant with an increasing shear rate at certain zones of shear rate were widened as the electric fields increased. Beyond the plateau region of the shear stress, stresses under various applied electric fields converged to a similar value without an electric field. This indicates that the ER properties induced by the applied electric field disappeared at large deformations. It is also noted that the Bingham plastic flow behavior of the MCM-41 ER system can be confirmed from the linear plot of the flow curve data given in Fig. 7(b). Similar behaviors of apparent shear viscosity were also observed as a function of the shear rate in Fig. 7(c); apparent shear viscosities at different electric fields again converged to the same value at high shear rates around 103/s.

These characteristic flow behaviors of the MCM-41 ER fluids are related to the internal particle structure induced by an applied electric field. Before shearing the ER fluid, the dispersed particles are aligned through the electric field direction making columnar structures, and these structures get stronger at higher electric field, so that the shear stresses and apparent shear viscosities of the ER fluids increased with the electric field as shown in Fig. 7. Subsequently, the chainlike structures of the particles were deformed and started to break down with a further increase in shear rate. However, the electrostatic interaction between the particles is apparently still dominant over the hydrodynamic forces between the particles and the medium under the increased shear rate. In this shear rate region, the shear stress curve shows a plateau and the shear viscosities that rapidly decrease. Above the critical points of the shear rate where the destruction rate of the column structures become faster than the column reforming rate by the electric field [32], the flow curves behave much like those without an electric field. The fibril structures are then broken into particles or particle clusters by shearing due to dominant hydrodynamic interactions, and eventually the ER effect virtually disappears.

Interestingly, it was observed that the shear stress increases monotonically but not linearly with the shear rates at zero electric field. It is not surprising to find such a non-Newtonian behavior even at zero electric field because of the high particle volume fraction in suspension, similar to polyaniline [33] or polymerâclay nanocomposites [34,35].

The apparent shear viscosities of MCM-41 ER fluids having three different particle concentrations (5, 10 and 20 wt.%) were also examined. A sample with 5wt.% MCM-41 was found to show hardly any ER effect, and the rest showed a similar shear viscosity behavior of ER fluids with the shear rate being the same as those given in Fig. 7(c). The âcritical particle concentrationâ above which the typical ER property is observed is noteworthy. A more detailed measurements of this will be published in a future communication.

In this study, MCM-41 was synthesized, and its ER performance was investigated for the first time. A typical ER behavior was observed except for relatively low particle concentrations in the suspension. Further investigations are in progress using mesoporous materials with different chemical compositions and structures. A polarization process of MCM-41 ER fluids will also be investigated and compared with that of ER fluids containing zeolites [16,18].

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: The authors wish to thank the referees for their critical comments and suggestions.

H. Conrad, Y. Chen, in: K.O. Havelka, F.E. Filisko (Eds.), Progress in Electrorheology, Plenum Press, New York, 1995, p. 55
J.S. Beck, G.H. Kuehl, D.H. Olson, J.L. Schelenker, G.D. Stucky, J.C. Varituli, US Patent 5,348,687, 1994

R.B. Borade, A. Clearfield, Synthesis of porous materials: zeolites, clays, and nanostructures, in: M.L. Occelli, H. Kessler (Eds.), Chemical Industries, vol. 69, Marcel Dekker, New York, 1996, p. 431
